The formation of TiO 2 nanotubes is generally associated with the presence of fluoride ions. At the high applied potential, the formed compact oxide layer, Ti(OH) 4, and Ti 4+ ions are chemically reacting with F − to form water-soluble fluoride complexes [TiF 6] 2−. The selective dissolution of aluminium oxide (Al 2O 3) and vanadium oxides (e.g., VO 2) might be occurred simultaneously at this stage. As a result, the balance of the metal oxidation and chemical dissolution of the oxide layer leads to the growth nanotubular structures. The dominant reaction mechanisms are proposed in Equations (7)–(9) as follows: TiO 2 + 6F − + 4H + → [TiF 6] 2− + H 2O (7)
Ti(OH) 4 + 6F − → [TiF 6] 2− + 4OH − (8)
Ti 4+ + 6F − → [TiF 6] 2−. (9)
